awd_abstract_narration:
The ability of the nervous system to change in response to experience, i.e., to exhibit 'plasticity', is a long-standing topic of inquiry in neuroscience. In particular, the role of ongoing sensory stimulation for the normal development and maintenance of sensory systems is a perennial area of interest.  Knowledge about these processes for the sense of smell lags behind the other senses, not least because of the difficulty in physically controlling an odor stimulus. This project advances our understanding of stimulus-induced changes olfactory processing and other mechanisms of smell, as well as sheds light on the tendency of physiological systems, like olfaction, to operate in a relatively stable equilibrium between interdependent elements, the process known as homeostasis.  The olfactory periphery affords an excellent model where all components of a homeostatic system can be ascertained. Besides advancing our understanding of the sense of smell and sensory plasticity, the studies may suggest design elements for incorporation into chemical detection devices ('electronic noses') with applications in robotics, disease diagnosis, and bomb detection. Integrated with the research project is student-mentoring, participation-broadening, and public outreach through active involvement of undergraduates, including members of underrepresented groups, and the development of an exhibit at a local children's museum. These aspects of the project improve human resources in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics, and, via the museum, may engage thousands of school students annually. 

This project addresses the universal problem of how our senses adjust to long-term changes in the stimulus environment. Such adaptability allows sensory systems to match the dynamic range of their receptors to the array of stimuli in the environment, which can vary dramatically in time and space. Little is known about the cellular mechanisms of these homeostasis-like processes. The Investigator and his colleagues have discovered a phenomenon in the olfactory periphery termed compensatory plasticity that has the signature of such a process. In the olfactory epithelium, odor deprivation causes an up-regulation of the transduction cascade and enhancement of physiological responses that seemingly compensate in low stimulus environments.  The previous work allowed only binary control of the odor environment (i.e., deprivation or no deprivation). In the current project, the responses of the olfactory system to odor stimulation history is examined using olfactometric methods that allow broader control of odor environments, including the type, complexity, concentration, and timing of odor exposure.  The dependent measures include transcriptomic, histological, physiological, and behavior endpoints, allowing a holistic analysis of compensatory plasticity that lays the groundwork for a mechanistic understanding of this process.  Results from these studies advance our understanding of olfactory plasticity as well as illuminate mechanisms of neural plasticity and homeostasis

por.por_cntn:
The primary goal of this grant was to determine to what extent and by what mechanism the sense of smell can be changed by experience, a characteristic termed plasticity by scientist who study the nervous system.  It has long been known that depriving animals of odors alters the structure and function of the parts of the nervous system that process smells (known collectively as the olfactory system). Originally, this was thought to happen only if the deprivation occurred early in life during a so-called critical period, but more recent studies suggest these effects occur throughout life.  The opposite manipulation, enrichment of an animal’s odor environment, also causes structural and functional changes in smell centers.   

Despite this history of plasticity studies in olfaction, the exact nature of the changes, their cause and function (if any), remains elusive.  In this grant we sought to clarify the effects of odor deprivation and enrichment in animals to determine if the olfactory system depends on ongoing stimulation by odors for its continuing operation or continuously adjusts itself to an ever-changing odor environment. We found that mice deprived of odors showed an enhanced response to them after seven days when compared to normal mice.  We also had showed, prior to this grant, that if we removed the deprivation, the enhanced responses disappeared within two weeks.  Lastly, we found that deprivation for up to a year duration had no detectable deleterious effects on the olfactory system.  

With respect to enrichment, the situation was more complex.  We were able to replicate and extend a classic study showing that certain inbred strains of mice indeed show enhanced responses to certain odors they were exposed to for a week.  However, not all strains showed this response and the effect was odor specific and reversible.  

Considered together, the current findings and previous work from the laboratory support the counterintuitive conclusion that both the enhancement seen in response to deprivation and that seen in response to odor enrichment are caused by the same underlying homeostatic mechanism, the purpose of which is to preserve sensory information flow no matter the odorant milieu. 

To further probe the effects of enrichment on olfaction, we used sophisticated computer-controlled behavioral test-chambers to measure the ability of mice to detect and discriminate structurally similar odors both before and after enrichment with these odors. We were able to measure among the highest sensitives ever reported for any species and thus were confident in our methods.  Nevertheless, we were unable to show any effect of prior enrichment with odors on olfactory acuity suggesting along with our previous experiments that enhancement effects are odor and strain specific rather than a general phenomenon.

With the help of collaborators, the current grant allowed us to shed light on certain other problems in olfaction. First, it has long been debated as to whether the olfactory system works, in part, like the chemist’s chemical mixture analyzer known as a chromatograph. We studied this problem by combing advanced mathematical modeling of odor flow through the nasal cavity with recordings of the electrical activity of the olfactory receptor cells. The results were inconsistent with the chromatographic mechanism of olfaction suggesting that this perennial hypothesis may be invalid.

Another spinoff from this grant was our study of a rodent model of mood disorders. For several decades the olfactory bulbectomized rodent has been touted as an animal model of depression and other mental disorders. Bulbectomy entails the removal of the first way-station in the brain carrying olfactory information from the outside to the inside. Rodents that undergo this procedure display a suite of abnormal behaviors including hyperactivity that can be remedied by drugs that modify mood in humans. The rationale for this model posits that the remaining parts of the brain reorganize in the weeks after the procedure to create a depressed mouse.  In contrast, our experiments demonstrate that the abnormal behaviors following bulbectomy---particularly hyperactivity---emerge immediately after the procedure, suggesting that loss of smell, not brain circuit reorganization, is the basis of the model.  A ramification of our finding is that olfactory bulbectomy in rodents may not be an appropriate model for mood disorders in humans as previously thought.

The broader impacts of this project are manifold. First, research supported by this grant has increased the knowledge-base in science: Nine peer-reviewed papers have been published from the grant in scientific journals that bear on any number of research areas in basic and applied fields of biology.  Second, grant-funded student research projects have influenced some of the participating students to pursue postbaccalaureate education in STEM fields. Third, resources available for student research were increased by virtue of grant-purchased equipment and supplies. These additional resources were particularly impactful because the host institutions are small, predominantly undergraduate schools that can ill afford student research equipment.
